course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Introduction to Comparative Politics
course.description: This course is designed to expose students with a broad survey of the important issues in the study of comparative politics. It will provide students with a set of commonly used concepts in understanding politics around the world and teach students the statistical skills to compare different political systems with quantitative data. The course is organized around major problems and concepts in comparative politics rather than around particular countries. The topics include comparative methodology, public policy, political economy, political communication, democracy and authoritarianism, ideology and political culture, nationalism and nation-state, revolution and social movement, political participation and representation, and political institutions. These concepts and themes will help students master more advanced topics in future courses.

reviews.author: Noel Li
reviews.title: Good common course if you are interested in the topic
reviews.comment_content:
Module 1: Introduction
Module 2: Comparative Methodology
Module 3: Public Policy
Module 4: Political Economy
Module 5: Political Communication
Module 6: Democracy and Authoritarianism
Module 7: Ideology and Political Culture
Module 8: Nationalism and National State
Module 9: Revolution and social movement
Module 10:Political Participation and Representation
Module 11:Political Institutions
For this sem, 9 assignments and 13 discussions total
There were reading materials and video to watch to accomplish some of those homework
Also there were 4 quizzes:
Content almost stick to the syllabus. Professor will teach some extra knowledge about the topic in textbook. Both all reading content required and some video indicated by prof will be tested in the quizzes.
Quizzes are not cumulated by some successive concepts should be remembered in order to score good grade for following quizzes. (For example, which country is democracy tested in quiz2 wouldn't be tested in quiz3 but the concept of democracy should be known after you learned that in class.)
Since prof has Chinese background and his own researches about Chinese politics (Mainland China), he taught some specific knowledge about Chinese politics, which is a gift for Mainlanders.
Overall, content is good enough for those who liikes politics.
reviews.comment_teaching: The course is recorded and you just need to finish it before the ddl of hw. Prof Tang is very kind and patient to explain every concept clearly with vivid examples. Also, review sessions were provided for the last three quizzes. He replied emails and answered my questions clearly. For the recorded classes, since Prof Tang spoke slowly(which is very funny, at least I think so), you can understand the content with 1.5x.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading of the quizzes is based on a curve. The highest score for each quiz will be treated as 15%. A make up
quiz is only allowed if the student presents a doctor’s note stating the student’s inability to take the quiz during the scheduled time. A make-up quiz will not be graded on a curve. No late written assignment/discussion will be accepted unless there is a doctor’s note stating the student’s inability to complete the assignment by the due date. Discussions and assignments will not be curved.  
Assignments 30%
Online Discussions 10%
Quizzes (15% eachx 4) 60%
Final grades will be awarded based on the following ranges:
A+ > 97 B+ 89-86 C+79-76 D+69-66 F< 59
A 96-94 B 85-83 C 75-73 D 65-63
A- 93-90 B- 82-80 C- 72-70 D-62-60
Mean for assignments and discussions are very high, so the grade is basically about quizzes. However, the curve for the quizzes is completely unclear and you will never know what point you exactly get.
My score for reference:
Assignment: 44.5/45 Discusssion: 63.5/65
Quiz 1: 37/42 mean:35.36 high:41 (lots of cheaters since there's no proctor and next 3 quizzes had proctors with camera requirements)
Quiz 2: 44/50 mean:38.39 high: 47
Quiz 3: 41/48 mean: 31.64 high:43
Quiz 4: 47/49 mean: 37.42 high: 49
Prof gave everyone who helped him finish the survey for his research one point to their total grade.
My total urve grade: unknown
Final letter grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: workload could be light if you have had some knowledge about politics and modern world history. If you know complete nothing, you can still finish hw and quizzes but you will spend much more time. Since textbook and videos all in English, your reading and listening abilities are very important. Test needs to remember everything about readings without cheat sheets, so that should be heavy workload before quizzes (though I think some students find their way cheating).

reviews.comment_teaching:
All lecture videos are pre-recorded, there is no real-time delivery.
You can only talk to the professors during the zoom meeting of review sessions for quizzes and quizzes. He talked very slow, 1.5x is better for understanding.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair.
Got below mean and above mean in quizzes (15%@,total:4)
0 in one of the assignments
almost full in discussions
final grade: B
Just pay more attention to the requirement of the questions, read through every single word.
And work hard for the quiz, u will be able to get an A.
I revised the course materials 1 day before the quiz, so if you study earlier, you can definitely get a better grade as the quizzes were all MC and all questions were easy, as long as you read the materials carefully, and memorise a few important definitions and names.
reviews.comment_workload:
Ard 10 discussions and 10 assignemnts.
Assignments carry a higher weighting and questions are of different styles. Discussion is just some short essays, however, sometimes you need to write in 100-200 words, you have to consider carefully what should be included in the essay. All work should use the concepts taught in lessons or course materials or you will lose some marks. Overall, the workload is acceptable but annoying as there are a lot of steps in some of the assignments like you have to make an excel sheet of a lot of data, if you cannot calculate the right answer, some marks will be lost.

reviews.comment_content: Not updated, recorded years ago. I think the book you bought is more updated compare with his lecture notes.
reviews.comment_teaching: All lectures are recorded, make sure to use at least 1.5x speed for watching.
reviews.comment_grading:
High mean with all assignments and discussions.
4 quizzes in total may be held on Saturday, Friday, and lecture time.
reviews.comment_workload: Around 2 assignments/quizzes per week to make sure you are following the lecture videos. Some are related to the lectures but some are not. Some of them are quite time-consuming as you have to watch some movies for around two hours.
